question: I was just diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and I have questions on options of treatment, greatly appreciate if you could get back to me as soon as possible. Thank you.

responses.gpt-5:
I’m really sorry you’re going through this. I can help you understand the main options and what to ask your team right away. The best plan depends on the cancer type, where it is, and your overall health, so I’ll give a clear overview and then tailor it if you share a few details.

Key questions that determine treatment
- Pathology: pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (most common) or pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (NET)? Grade if NET?
- Stage/resectability: resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced (unresectable), or metastatic? Any blood vessel involvement?
- Sites of spread (if any): liver, lung, peritoneum, nodes.
- Your fitness/comorbidities: performance status, weight loss, jaundice, diabetes.
- Have you had genetic testing? (Germline testing for inherited mutations and tumor profiling for actionable targets.)

Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (most common) – current standard options

1) If it appears removable (resectable)
- Surgery first or chemotherapy first (neoadjuvant) depending on center preference and features.
- Surgery types: Whipple (pancreatic head), distal pancreatectomy ± spleen (tail), occasionally total pancreatectomy.
- Chemotherapy is routine either before or after surgery:
  - Fit patients: modified FOLFIRINOX is preferred.
  - Others: gemcitabine + capecitabine; sometimes gemcitabine alone.
- Radiation: sometimes after or before surgery in select cases.

2) Borderline resectable
- Goal: shrink/contain tumor and increase chances of a complete surgery.
- First: multi-agent chemotherapy (most commonly modified FOLFIRINOX or NALIRIFOX).
- Then restaging; some centers add short-course radiation (SBRT) before surgery.
- Proceed to surgery if imaging and surgeon think it’s feasible.

3) Locally advanced (unresectable, no distant spread)
- First: systemic chemotherapy (modified FOLFIRINOX or NALIRIFOX preferred if you’re fit; gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel if not).
- After several months: if stable/responding, some centers use consolidation chemoradiation/SBRT; a minority may convert to surgery.
- Clinical trials strongly encouraged.

4) Metastatic
- First-line chemotherapy (choose based on fitness and preferences):
  - Modified FOLFIRINOX (q2 weeks) OR NALIRIFOX (FDA-approved 2024) are most active if you’re robust enough.
  - Gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel is a strong alternative.
  - If frail: single-agent gemcitabine or 5-FU/capecitabine.
- Second-line examples: after gem-based therapy, 5-FU + liposomal irinotecan; after FOLFIRINOX, gemcitabine ± nab-paclitaxel or clinical trial.

Biomarker-driven options (why testing is urgent)
- Everyone with pancreatic cancer should get:
  - Germline testing (e.g., BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM, Lynch genes). If BRCA1/2 or PALB2: platinum chemo is favored; some may get olaparib maintenance if metastatic disease is stable after platinum.
  - Tumor profiling (next-generation sequencing) to look for:
    - MSI-H/dMMR or high TMB: pembrolizumab (immunotherapy).
    - NTRK fusion: larotrectinib or entrectinib.
    - BRAF V600E: dabrafenib + trametinib.
    - HER2-positive: trastuzumab deruxtecan (tumor-agnostic approval).
    - KRAS G12C: consider clinical trials; targeted drugs are not yet broadly approved in pancreas.
- Ask your team if both germline and tumor testing have been sent; results can change the plan.

If your diagnosis is a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (NET)
- Options differ by grade and spread:
  - Surgery if localized.
  - Somatostatin analogs (octreotide/lanreotide) for symptom control and growth slowing.
  - Targeted therapies (everolimus, sunitinib), PRRT (Lu-177 dotatate) for somatostatin-receptor–positive disease, or chemo (e.g., CAPTEM) in more aggressive cases.
  - High-grade neuroendocrine carcinoma: platinum + etoposide.

Important supportive care from day one
- Biliary obstruction/jaundice: endoscopic stent to relieve itching, infection risk, and enable chemo.
- Nutrition: early referral; high-protein/high-calorie plan; consider pancreatic enzyme replacement (pancrelipase) if greasy stools, bloating, weight loss.
- Pain: don’t suffer in silence; options include strong pain meds and celiac plexus block.
- Blood clots: pancreatic cancer has a high risk; ask if preventive anticoagulation is right for you during chemo.
- Diabetes and digestion: close glucose management; enzymes, vitamins, and acid suppression often help.
- Early palliative care improves symptoms and quality of life and can be integrated alongside treatment.

Where to be treated
- Outcomes are better at high-volume pancreatic centers. Consider a second opinion at an NCI-designated center or a major pancreatic program, especially before deciding on surgery or if considering neoadjuvant therapy.

Clinical trials
- Trials are a key part of care at all stages and may offer access to new drugs (KRAS-targeted agents, combinations with immunotherapy, vaccines, etc.). If you’d like, share your city/ZIP and I can help you find options near you.

What to do this week
- Get and keep copies of: pathology report, CT/MRI/PET reports, operative/endoscopy notes, CA 19-9 level, and any genetic/tumor testing.
- Ask your oncologist:
  - What is my exact stage and resectability?
  - Am I a candidate for surgery now or after chemo?
  - Which first-line regimen do you recommend for me and why (modified FOLFIRINOX, NALIRIFOX, or gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel)?
  - Have you ordered both germline and tumor genomic testing?
  - Should I see radiation oncology now or later?
  - Are there clinical trials I’m eligible for?
  - Do I need a port placed and when can I start treatment?
  - Should I start pancreatic enzymes and meet nutrition and palliative care?
- If jaundiced or itchy, ask about urgent stent placement.

If you share a few details—pathology type, stage or scan summary, whether it has spread, your age/fitness, and any test results—I’ll tailor this to you and help you prepare specific questions for your next appointment.

A couple quick questions so I can tailor options:

- Do they have insurance constraints (plan/network)?
- Are you looking for a full evaluation or a second opinion/virtual consult?

What to gather now:

If you share your location and any preferences, I can suggest specific named doctors/clinics nearby and provide direct scheduling contacts and links for second opinions.

question: I need of recommendation for tumor removal. I am currently receiving treatment at a cancer center. Under a clinical trial for radiation and chemotherapy treatment for several months now. Stage 3. Surgical team does not feel comfortable performing surgery.

responses.gpt-5:
I’m sorry you’re dealing with this. When surgery is questioned at Stage 3, it’s usually because of tumor extent, involvement of critical structures, or overall surgical risk—but a second look by a high‑volume specialist team can sometimes change options.

A few questions that would help me tailor suggestions:
- What cancer type and where is the tumor located?
- What country/state are you in?
- What treatments have you received so far (drug names, radiation dose/dates)?
- What reasons did the surgeons give for not proceeding (e.g., blood vessel involvement, margins unlikely, medical risk)?
- How has the tumor responded on recent scans?

Actions you can take now
- Ask for a multidisciplinary tumor board review: Request that your case be re-presented to the hospital’s tumor board (surgical, medical, radiation oncology, radiology, pathology).
- Seek a high-volume surgical second opinion:
  - Look for an NCI-Designated Comprehensive Cancer Center (US) or an equivalent national referral center. These centers often have subspecialty surgeons (hepatobiliary, thoracic, colorectal, sarcoma, head & neck, etc.) who handle complex resections.
  - If you share your location, I can help identify nearby centers. Otherwise, search “NCI-Designated Cancer Centers” or your country’s national cancer network.
  - Many centers offer remote/virtual second opinions; you can keep your current team while you explore this.
- Clarify trial constraints: Some clinical trials limit surgery during enrollment. Ask your trial PI:
  - Does the protocol allow surgery after response?
  - What criteria would trigger surgical reevaluation?
  - If surgery elsewhere is advised, what are the steps to pause or withdraw safely from the trial?
- Ask targeted questions of the surgeons:
  - Exactly what makes this unresectable or too high-risk?
  - Would additional downstaging (more chemo, different regimen, more radiation) make surgery feasible?
  - Could a more specialized procedure (e.g., vascular reconstruction, extended resection) change the picture at a high-volume center?
  - What are the expected outcomes with and without surgery?
- Discuss non-surgical local options if surgery isn’t possible: definitive chemoradiation, stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT), ablation or embolization (for certain organs), or organ-preserving “watch-and-wait” strategies in select cancers after complete clinical response. Suitability depends on cancer type.

What to gather for a second opinion
- Most recent clinic notes and oncologic summary.
- All imaging reports and image files (CT/MRI/PET on CD or via image-share) with dates.
- Pathology report plus slides/blocks access; molecular/biomarker results.
- Radiation summary (dose, fields, plan) and chemotherapy regimen details (drugs, cycles, dates).
- Any operative or endoscopy reports.

Optimization if surgery might be possible later
- Ask about “prehabilitation”: nutrition support, exercise/physical therapy, smoking cessation, anemia management. These can improve surgical candidacy and recovery.

Supportive care
- Consider early palliative care for symptom control and quality of life alongside active treatment; it’s not the same as end-of-life care and improves outcomes in many cancers.

If you share your cancer type and location, I can:
- Point you to appropriate high-volume centers/surgeons for that disease.
- Help draft an email to request a second opinion.
- Help review your questions for the tumor board.

I’m not a doctor, but I can help you navigate options and prepare for conversations with your team.

question: I have had pancreatitis for years. Due to not being able to afford medical insurance, I have not had the proper treatment or checkups. I am concerned about pancreatic cancer.

responses.gpt-5:
I’m sorry you’ve been dealing with this for so long without regular care. Your concern is understandable.

What we know
- Chronic pancreatitis does increase the risk of pancreatic cancer compared with the general population, but most people with chronic pancreatitis never develop cancer.
- For non‑hereditary chronic pancreatitis, the lifetime risk is estimated around 4% after 20 years. Risk is higher with smoking, heavy alcohol use, and certain genetic causes (hereditary pancreatitis due to PRSS1 mutations can carry a much higher risk).

Warning signs that should be checked promptly (go to urgent care/ER if severe)
- Yellowing of skin/eyes, very dark urine, pale/greasy stools, or itchy skin
- Unexplained weight loss, loss of appetite
- New or worsening upper belly pain that may go to the back
- New‑onset diabetes or a sudden big change in blood sugar control
- Persistent vomiting, fevers, or inability to keep fluids down

Screening and tests
- Routine screening for pancreatic cancer is not recommended for everyone with chronic pancreatitis.
- Surveillance is recommended for people at very high risk (for example, hereditary pancreatitis from PRSS1 mutations or strong family history). Typical surveillance uses MRI/MRCP and/or endoscopic ultrasound annually at specialty centers.
- CA 19‑9 blood tests are not reliable for screening and can be elevated by pancreatitis; they’re not recommended as a stand‑alone check.
- If you have new or concerning symptoms, the first-line imaging is usually a pancreas‑protocol CT or an MRI/MRCP. Endoscopic ultrasound may follow if something looks suspicious.

Affordable ways to get evaluated without insurance (US)
- Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs): sliding‑scale primary care, basic labs, and referrals.
  - Find one: findahealthcenter.hrsa.gov
- Nonprofit hospital financial assistance: ask about “charity care” or “financial assistance policy.” Many hospitals must provide discounted or free care based on income.
- Teaching hospitals/academic GI clinics: often have charity programs or reduced self‑pay rates.
- Imaging cash prices: independent imaging centers often offer lower cash prices than hospitals. Call and ask for the “self‑pay/cash price” for:
  - MRI/MRCP: often $500–$900
  - Pancreas‑protocol CT: often $300–$600
- Labs to consider at a low‑cost clinic or community lab:
  - Comprehensive metabolic panel, liver tests, bilirubin
  - Hemoglobin A1c or fasting glucose (screen for diabetes)
  - If you have greasy stools/weight loss: fecal elastase to check for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI)

Reducing your risk and managing symptoms now
- Don’t smoke; smoking is a major risk for both pancreatitis complications and pancreatic cancer.
  - Free help: 1‑800‑QUIT‑NOW; many states offer free nicotine patches.
- Avoid alcohol; if stopping is hard: SAMHSA 1‑800‑662‑HELP for free, confidential support.
- Nutrition: small, low‑fat meals; adequate protein; consider a dietitian if available. Watch for signs of malabsorption (greasy, foul‑smelling stools, bloating, weight loss).
- Pancreatic enzymes (PERT) if you have EPI symptoms: prescription products (pancrelipase such as Creon/Zenpep) work best. Ask clinics about patient‑assistance programs from manufacturers if cost is a barrier.
- Vitamins: people with chronic pancreatitis/EPI can become low in vitamins A, D, E, K; a clinician can guide supplements and bone health (vitamin D/calcium).
- Diabetes screening yearly (or sooner if symptoms): frequent thirst/urination, fatigue, blurry vision, unexpected weight loss.

If you may be high‑risk for pancreatic cancer
- Consider a referral to a high‑risk pancreas clinic if any of these apply:
  - Known hereditary pancreatitis (PRSS1) or other high‑risk gene mutation
  - Two or more close relatives with pancreatic cancer
  - One close relative diagnosed under age 50
- These clinics coordinate MRI/EUS surveillance and genetic counseling; many have financial assistance.

How I can tailor advice
If you’re comfortable, tell me:
- Your age and how many years you’ve had pancreatitis
- Cause (if known): alcohol, gallstones, high triglycerides, autoimmune, or hereditary
- Smoking status and alcohol use
- Any family history of pancreatic or related cancers
- Current symptoms (pain, weight loss, stool changes, jaundice)
- Whether you’ve ever had enzymes prescribed or been told you have diabetes

If you’re having severe pain, jaundice, persistent vomiting, fever, or can’t keep fluids down, please seek urgent care or an ER.

I can help you find nearby low‑cost clinics/imaging and draft what to ask for at a first visit.

question: My loved one recently got diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. Please help me as I am feeling helpless and overwhelmed.

responses.gpt-5:
I’m really sorry you’re going through this. Feeling helpless and overwhelmed is completely understandable. You don’t have to carry this alone—I can help you break this into manageable steps and be here as you navigate it.

If you’re up for it, here are practical things you can do next.

Right now (to reduce overwhelm)
- Take one small step: choose a single task below and do only that today.
- Ask one trusted person to be your point person for updates and logistics.
- Write down your top 2–3 questions for the next appointment.
- Breathe: Inhale for 4, hold 4, exhale 6, repeat for 2–3 minutes.

Medical next steps
- Get organized:
  - Gather and keep copies of all reports: pathology, imaging (ask for CDs), lab results, medication list, allergies.
  - Start a shared folder or notebook for appointments, symptoms, and questions.
- Care team:
  - Request care at a high-volume pancreatic cancer center or ask for a second opinion at one. Outcomes are better where they do this a lot.
  - Ask for a nurse navigator and oncology social worker—they can coordinate appointments, resources, and support.
- Understand the plan:
  - Ask: What stage is it? Is it considered resectable, borderline, locally advanced, or metastatic?
  - What are the goals of treatment right now (cure, control, symptom relief)?
  - What options apply: surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, clinical trials?
- Testing that matters:
  - Germline genetic testing is recommended for all pancreatic cancer patients (e.g., BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM, Lynch). This can guide treatment and inform family risk.
  - Tumor profiling/biomarker testing (MSI/dMMR, NTRK, BRCA/HRD, KRAS variant, TMB). Ask if testing has been done and how it affects options.
- Clinical trials:
  - Ask if there’s a relevant trial now or after initial treatment. I can help search if you share location and stage.
- Symptoms to flag promptly:
  - Worsening jaundice (yellow eyes/skin), fever 100.4°F/38°C or higher, uncontrolled pain, vomiting or inability to keep fluids, shortness of breath, new confusion, severe constipation, chest pain, one-sided leg swelling.

Managing common issues
- Pain: ask about a pain plan; options include medications and nerve blocks (celiac plexus block).
- Nutrition and weight loss: request a referral to an oncology dietitian. Pancreatic enzyme capsules (e.g., CREON) may help if there’s greasy stools, bloating, or weight loss.
- Diabetes/blood sugar swings: new or worsening diabetes is common—ask about monitoring and management.
- Biliary blockage/itching: may need a stent—bring this up if eyes/skin look yellow or urine is dark.
- Mood/sleep: depression and anxiety are common; ask about counseling, medications, or sleep strategies. Early palliative care can help with symptoms and coping (it’s not just end-of-life).

Caregiver support (for you)
- Boundaries and roles: it’s okay to say “I can do X; I need help with Y.”
- Delegate tasks using tools like Lotsa Helping Hands, CaringBridge, or a shared calendar.
- Practical help: meals, rides, childcare, pet care, pharmacy runs. People want to help—give them specific jobs.
- Work and finances: ask the social worker about FMLA, short-term disability, insurance case managers, medication copay assistance.
- Legal basics: encourage completion of an advance directive and medical power of attorney; have HIPAA releases so you can speak with the team.

Questions to bring to the next appointment
- What is the exact diagnosis and stage? Is it resectable/borderline/locally advanced/metastatic?
- What treatment do you recommend first and why? What are the goals of that treatment?
- What tests or biomarker results do we still need?
- Am I a candidate for surgery now or after treatment? If surgery is an option, how many Whipple operations does your surgeon do per year?
- What side effects should we expect and how will you help manage them?
- Who do we call after hours? What symptoms are urgent?
- Are there clinical trials that fit me now?
- Should we start pancreatic enzymes or see a dietitian?
- Can we meet palliative care early for symptom support?
- Would you support a second opinion? (Most teams encourage this.)

Reliable resources and help lines
- Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN): patient services, clinical trial matching, nutrition and financial navigation. 877-2-PANCAN (877-272-6226), pancan.org
- American Cancer Society: 24/7 information and rides/housing assistance. 800-227-2345, cancer.org
- CancerCare: free counseling, support groups, financial help. 800-813-4673, cancercare.org
- NCCN Guidelines for Patients: clear, credible treatment overviews. nccn.org/patients
- NCI-designated cancer centers: cancer.gov/research/infrastructure/cancer-centers

If you want, I can:
- Help you draft a one-page medical summary to bring to visits.
- Compile a personalized question list for your specific situation.
- Search for high-volume centers or trials near you.
- Review and explain any reports you have (pathology, imaging, labs).

A gentle note about emotions
- What you’re feeling is a normal response to a hard situation. Try tiny, regular self-care: short walks, hydration, a consistent sleep window, 10 minutes of “worry time,” and brief check-ins with a friend.
- If you ever feel like you might hurt yourself or can’t keep yourself safe, in the U.S. call/text 988; otherwise use local emergency services.

If you’re comfortable sharing: What stage or tests have they told you about so far? Where are you located? And what’s the one thing that would help you most today—information, logistics, or emotional support? I’m here with you.

question: My loved one has stage IV pancreatic cancer and their chemotherapy stopped working. Is there any experimental treatments or clinical trials available?

responses.gpt-5:
I’m really sorry you and your loved one are facing this. When standard chemotherapy stops working in stage IV pancreatic cancer, clinical trials are often the best next step. There are trials open in many categories, and which ones fit depends on tumor biology, prior treatments, overall health, and location.

What to do first
- Ask the oncologist to order comprehensive molecular profiling on tumor tissue and/or a blood “liquid biopsy,” plus germline (inherited) testing if not already done. Results can unlock FDA‑approved options or make you eligible for specific trials.
  - Key biomarkers to check: MSI‑H/dMMR, TMB‑high, NTRK/ALK/RET/ROS1 fusions, BRAF V600E, HER2 amplification/overexpression, KRAS subtype (G12D, G12C, etc.), BRCA1/2, PALB2, ATM and other DNA‑repair genes, MTAP deletion.
- Ask for a referral to an NCI‑designated cancer center or a high‑volume pancreatic cancer program; they run and know about more trials.

Potential options if a target is found
- MSI‑H/dMMR or TMB‑high: Pembrolizumab (FDA tumor‑agnostic approval).
- NTRK fusion: Larotrectinib or entrectinib (tumor‑agnostic).
- BRAF V600E: Dabrafenib + trametinib (tumor‑agnostic).
- HER2‑positive: Trastuzumab deruxtecan has tumor‑agnostic approval; some centers also run HER2‑directed trials.
- BRCA1/2 or PALB2: Platinum chemo sensitivity; PARP inhibitors and DNA‑damage response trials are options. Discuss current approval status and trial access with the oncologist.
- KRAS G12C (rare in pancreas): Access mainly via trials of adagrasib or sotorasib combinations.

Clinical trial categories commonly enrolling pancreatic cancer
- KRAS‑directed therapies:
  - G12D inhibitors (for tumors with KRAS G12D): examples include MRTX1133 and RMC‑9805 in phase 1/2 trials.
  - Pan‑RAS(ON) inhibitors: for multiple KRAS variants (e.g., RMC‑6236).
  - Combinations targeting KRAS pathways (SHP2, MEK, EGFR) including adagrasib or sotorasib combos if G12C.
- DNA damage response inhibitors:
  - PARP, ATR, WEE1, or DNA‑PK inhibitors, often for BRCA/PALB2/ATM alterations or broader homologous recombination deficiency.
- Antibody‑drug conjugates (ADCs):
  - TROP2‑targeted (e.g., sacituzumab govitecan; datopotamab deruxtecan) and others under study in PDAC.
- Immunotherapy combinations:
  - CD40 agonists, CXCR4 inhibitors, STING/TLR agonists, adenosine/TGF‑β/FAK inhibitors combined with chemo or PD‑1/L1 blockade.
- Cellular therapies:
  - CAR‑T or TCR therapies targeting mesothelin or CLDN18.2 in selected patients, depending on tumor expression and center.
- Tumor vaccines/neoantigen vaccines:
  - Personalized mRNA or peptide vaccines and dendritic‑cell approaches, often combined with checkpoint inhibitors.

How to find active trials
- PanCAN Clinical Trial Finder (and free Patient Services): pancan.org or 877‑2‑PANCAN (877‑272‑6226). They can do a personalized search and help with questions and logistics.
- NCI Cancer Trials: cancer.gov/clinicaltrials or 1‑800‑4‑CANCER. Filter for “pancreatic adenocarcinoma,” “metastatic,” “recruiting,” and add keywords like “KRAS G12D,” “HER2,” “PARP,” etc.
- ClinicalTrials.gov: Use filters for recruiting/active, your city/state, and biomarker keywords.
- Ask nearby NCI‑designated Comprehensive Cancer Centers whether they have pancreatic‑specific trials. Many centers have trial navigators.

Typical eligibility considerations
- Performance status (often ECOG 0–1, sometimes 0–2).
- Lab values (blood counts, liver/kidney function; biliary stents to control bilirubin can help meet criteria).
- Prior therapies and washout periods.
- Ability to travel and undergo biopsies or frequent visits.

If no trial is feasible right now
- Discuss other systemic options your oncologist feels reasonable for symptom control.
- Consider early palliative care; it can improve both quality of life and, in some cases, survival while you pursue trials.
- Ask about expanded access/compassionate use for promising drugs when trials aren’t an option.

If you’d like, I can help narrow to a short list of trials. Please share:
- Country/region you can travel to
- Age and current performance status (for example, how active they are day‑to‑day)
- Prior chemotherapy regimens and when they were given
- Any molecular profiling or germline results so far (exact mutations/biomarkers)
- Any lab limitations (especially bilirubin) or other major medical issues

I’m here to help you sort through options and questions for the oncology team.

question: My loved one was recently diagnosed with stage IV pancreatic cancer. Both my family and the patient are completely overwhelmed and don't know where to start.

responses.gpt-5:
I’m really sorry you’re all facing this. Feeling overwhelmed is completely normal. Here’s a simple, practical roadmap to help you get oriented and take the next steps.

What stage IV means
- The cancer has spread to other organs. Treatments aim to control the cancer, ease symptoms, and prolong/maintain quality of life. Some people choose active treatment; others focus on comfort. Either path is valid and can be revisited anytime.

First 1–2 weeks: a focused checklist
1) Assemble the care team
- Medical oncologist with pancreatic cancer experience (ideally at, or via a second opinion from, a high-volume or NCI-designated cancer center).
- Nurse navigator or social worker, palliative care specialist (for symptom support from the start), oncology dietitian, and primary care.
- Consider a second opinion; a brief delay to do this is usually okay.

2) Gather medical records
- Pathology report (biopsy), all imaging (CT/MRI/PET) with reports, recent labs, operative/procedure notes (e.g., stent placement), medication/allergy list.
- Keep a binder or shared drive. Bring a trusted person to visits and a written question list.

3) Ask about molecular and genetic testing now
- Tumor testing: MSI-H/dMMR, BRCA1/2, PALB2, NTRK, RET, BRAF, KRAS G12C and other targets that can open doors to specific drugs or trials.
- Germline testing (blood/saliva) for inherited mutations (BRCA1/2, PALB2, etc.)—important for treatment and for family.

4) Discuss first-line treatment options
- Common regimens: FOLFIRINOX or gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel. Choice depends on overall strength/side effects, liver/bilirubin levels, and goals.
- Ask about: expected benefits, side effects, schedule, whether a port is recommended, and supportive meds (anti-nausea, bowel regimen).
- If bilirubin is high from blockage, a biliary stent often needs to be placed before chemo.
- Ask about clinical trials. You can start standard therapy and still enter some trials later.

5) Engage palliative care early
- This is about better symptom control, coping, and decision support—alongside cancer treatment.

Managing symptoms and daily life
- Pain: Don’t suffer in silence. Options include short/long-acting pain meds, nerve pain meds, and celiac plexus block for difficult pancreatic pain. Keep a bowel regimen with opioids.
- Nutrition/weight loss: Small, frequent, high-calorie/protein meals; meet an oncology dietitian. Signs of pancreas enzyme insufficiency (greasy/oily stools, bloating, weight loss) may improve with prescription enzymes—ask about pancreatic enzyme replacement.
- Nausea and appetite: Many helpful meds exist; ask about proactive anti-nausea plans. Appetite/weight support can be addressed.
- Jaundice/itching, fevers, or chills: Could signal bile duct blockage or infection—call urgently.
- Blood clots: Pancreatic cancer raises risk. New leg swelling/pain, sudden chest pain, or shortness of breath need urgent care.
- Diabetes/blood sugars: Can worsen; coordinate with primary care or endocrinology.

Red flags that need prompt medical attention
- Fever 100.4 F (38 C) or higher, shaking chills
- Worsening jaundice or severe itching
- Uncontrolled pain, vomiting, dehydration, confusion
- Sudden shortness of breath or chest pain
- New leg swelling/pain, severe constipation with pain

Talking with the oncologist: good questions
- What treatment do you recommend first and why?
- What benefit can we realistically expect? How will we know it’s working?
- What side effects are most likely and how do we prevent/manage them?
- Will you order tumor molecular profiling and germline testing?
- Are there clinical trials we should consider now or later?
- Can we meet palliative care and a dietitian now?
- Who do we call after hours for symptoms? What are “red flags” for the ER?
- How will we coordinate care if we seek a second opinion?

Planning and support
- Clarify goals and preferences: What matters most to your loved one (time, function, side effects to avoid, important events)?
- Advance care planning: Choose a medical decision-maker, complete advance directives/POLST when you’re ready; these can change anytime.
- Hospice: When treatment is no longer helping or symptoms/energy decline, early hospice can greatly improve comfort and support at home.

Practical caregiver tips
- Pick a point person for medical calls and a shared calendar for appointments/meds.
- Accept help—meals, rides, child/pet care. Caregiver burnout is real; build breaks in.
- Keep a simple symptom/weight log and bring it to visits.

Trustworthy resources
- Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) Patient Services: clinical trial matching, second-opinion and expert center guidance, nutrition/symptom help. 877-2-PANCAN (877-272-6226), pancan.org
- National Cancer Institute (NCI): information and NCI-designated centers. 800-4-CANCER (800-422-6237), cancer.gov
- NCCN Guidelines for Patients: Pancreatic Cancer (free, plain-language): nccn.org/patients
- American Cancer Society: 800-227-2345, cancer.org
- CancerCare: free counseling and support groups. 800-813-4673, cancercare.org
- Triage Cancer: practical and legal/financial resources. triagecancer.org
- Imerman Angels: one-on-one peer mentor support. 866-463-7626, imermanangels.org
